name: folk

folk noun
(PEOPLE)
Add to word list
Add to word list
B2 [ plural ] mainly UK (US usually folks) people, especially those of a particular group or type: old folk There are a lot of old folk living in this town.ordinary folk Ordinary folk can't afford cars like that. folks [ plural ]
[ as form of address ] informal used when speaking informally to a group of people: All right, folks, dinner's ready!
B2 someone's parents: I'm going home to see my folks.

More examplesFewer examplesCan I get you folks some drinks?The folk around here are unhappy about the proposed motorway.The law is designed to protect folk like us.Can the folks at the back hear me?There are a lot of old folk in the village.

folk noun
(MUSIC)
B1 [ U ] (also folk music) modern music and songs that are written in a style similar to that of traditional music: folk (music) I enjoy listening to folk (music).folk singer She achieved her greatest success as a folk singer.folk club She began singing in folk clubs around the country.folk festival The city hosts the largest free folk festival in the country.

traditional to or typical of a particular group or country, especially one where people mainly live in the countryside, and usually passed on from parents to their children over a long period of time: folk culture
B1 Folk art expresses something about the lives and feelings of ordinary people in a particular group or country, especially those living in the countryside: folk art folk dancing
